questions.text: The image below shows strangulation by Spanish windlass method. What type of strangulation method does it belong to? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Garroting

 

Spanish windlass

 

Method: It involves tightening an iron collar (Spanish windlass) around the neck and forcing a spike against the neck into the spinal cord.

 

Garroting- It involves attacking the victim by throwing the ligature from behind over the victim's neck and then tightened by twisting with a lever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bansdola: A method of strangulation where a ligature is applied in a different manner, often using a stick or rod to twist and tighten the ligature.

 

Option C. Mugging: Refers to a method where the assailant uses their limbs, such as the crook of their elbow, to compress the neck.

 

Option D. Throttling: Throttling involves using hands to manually compress the neck, leading to asphyxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Spanish windlass method of strangulation, shown in the image, belongs to the category of garroting, which involves the use of a ligature tightened by a lever or similar mechanism.

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Suggillation

 

The image shows post mortem staining on the back, also called suggillation. Post-mortem staining (PMS) is the settling of the blood in the dependent portions of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tattooing: Tattoos appear as distinct, well-defined patterns or designs, often in various colors. Tattoos can be located anywhere on the body and are not necessarily confined to dependent areas. They are typically intentional markings made by injecting ink into the skin.

 

Option C. Putrefaction: The body becomes greenish in colour in putrefaction. Later it becomes blackish.

 

Option D. Decomposition: Same explanation as that of putrefaction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Mortem Staining (PMS)

 

  •  It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • Other names of PMS are:
    • Hypostasis
    • livor mortis
    • Vibices
    • Suggillation
    • Postmortem Lividity
    • Cadaveric lividity
    • Darkening of death
  •  It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth.

 

Section 193 IPC (Now, BNS 229): Punishment for Perjury (false evidence). Specifies the punishment for giving false evidence under oath, which can be up to 7 years of imprisonment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath but does not specify the punishment. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence but not directly related to perjury. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years, but it is not specifically for perjury. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (upto 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 07 years. (BNS 238)

questions.text: Who conducts inquest in police custodial death? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Judicial magistrate

 

In India, an inquest can be conducted by either the police or a magistrate. A police inquest is the most common type of inquest. However, a magistrate inquest is conducted in specific cases. There are two types of magistrates who can conduct inquests: an executive magistrate and a judicial magistrate.

 

  • Executive Magistrate Inquest: This is performed in cases of dowry deaths and exhumation.
  • Judicial Magistrate Inquest: This is conducted in cases of custodial deaths, which can occur in various forms of custody such as police custody, prison, psychiatric hospitals, or rehabilitation homes where an under-trial accused might be placed.

 

Therefore, in the event of a police custodial death, the inquest is conducted by a judicial magistrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Higher police official: While higher police officials may be involved in various administrative and investigative roles, they do not conduct inquests in cases of custodial deaths. The judicial magistrate is the designated authority for this purpose to ensure an unbiased investigation.

 

Option C. Medical examiner: A medical examiner conducts autopsies and determines the cause of death, but does not conduct inquests. The role of the medical examiner is critical in providing medical evidence that supports the inquest.

 

Option D. Coroner: The office of the coroner is not part of the Indian legal system. Instead, the role typically carried out by a coroner in other jurisdictions is fulfilled by magistrates in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the inquest for a police custodial death is conducted by a judicial magistrate, ensuring an impartial investigation into the circumstances surrounding the death.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drowning

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to drowning.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway

  • Water in the stomach and small intestine

  • Water in middle ear

  • Cerebral edema

  • Bloated and cyanosed face

  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.

  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs

  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils

  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours

  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.

  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.

  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.

  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanging: Typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck, not frothing.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Often shows signs of external trauma to the neck, such as bruising or fractures, but not frothing.

 

Option D. Traumatic asphyxia: This results from severe chest compression, leading to petechiae and cyanosis but not usually frothing from the nose and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

questions.text:
What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Amyl Nitrite
B. Sodium Nitrite
C. Sodium Thiosulphate
D. Benzyl Thiocyanate
E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABC

 

Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome C oxidase, a key enzyme in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia and lactic acidosis. The treatment for cyanide poisoning involves agents that either bind to cyanide, facilitating its excretion, or convert it into a less toxic form.

 

A. Amyl Nitrite and B. Sodium Nitrite: These compounds oxidize hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome C oxidase. This process frees cytochrome C oxidase and forms cyanmethemoglobin.

 

C. Sodium Thiosulphate: This compound acts directly by converting cyanmethemoglobin to thiocyanate, which is less toxic and is excreted in the urine. Additionally, it directly breaks the bond between cytochrome C oxidase and cyanide.

 

D. Benzyl Thiocyanate: This is not a recognized treatment for cyanide poisoning and does not have the properties needed to detoxify cyanide.

 

E. Sodium Nitroprusside: This compound, while containing cyanide groups, is not used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning. It is actually a source of cyanide and is used for different medical purposes, such as vasodilation in hypertensive emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase.

Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine
