questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the picture given below? (AIIMS May 2018,)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

 

The image shows aconite, a highly toxic plant. All parts of the aconite plant are poisonous, not just the roots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Causes AV block: Correct statement. Aconite poisoning causes AV block due to its effects on the heart.

 

Option C. Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine: Correct statement. Atropine is used to counteract the bradycardia and AV block caused by aconite poisoning.

 

Option D. Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant: Correct statement. "Mitha zeher" is a common name for aconite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite:

 

  • All parts of the plant are poisonous.
  • Aconite is also called as - monkhood, mitha zeher, bish, and bikh.
  • Method of poisoning - It is a cardiac poison and causes AV block, bradycardia.
  • Treatment of choice - Atropine

questions.text: A dead body of a baby is brought for autopsy which is alleged to be a case of spontaneous abortion. On autopsy, ossification center of Talus is seen. What is the minimum gestational age of baby? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7 months

 

Explanation:

 

The appearance of the ossification center in the talus occurs at around 7 months of gestation.

 

Key points to remember related to gestational age of 7th month:

 

  • Ossification centre - Talus, S2, and S3: Appear at 7 months of intrauterine age.
  • Age of Viability: 7 months of gestation, the child can have a separate existence from the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossification Centers and Gestational Age

questions.text: A man wears female heels and a female dress to get sexual arousal. He is not interested in males. What is the diagnosis ? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic Fetishism

 

Transvestic Fetishism is a condition where an individual wears clothing of the opposite sex primarily to achieve sexual arousal. The key aspect of this disorder is the act of cross-dressing for the purpose of sexual gratification, not because of a desire to be of the opposite gender or any issues with gender identity. The patient described is not interested in males and is engaging in cross-dressing purely for sexual arousal, fitting the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender Dysphoria involves a conflict between an individual’s biological sex and their gender identity, such as a biologically male person identifying as female or vice versa. There is no indication in this case of any gender identity issues; the patient cross-dresses purely for sexual arousal.

 

Option C. Homosexuality: Homosexuality refers to a sexual orientation characterized by attraction to individuals of the same sex. The scenario explicitly states that the man is not interested in males, ruling out homosexuality as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is the act of gaining sexual pleasure from watching others when they are naked or engaged in sexual activity, usually without their knowledge or consent. There is no element of voyeuristic behavior described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic Fetishism is characterized by cross-dressing for sexual arousal without any associated desire to change one’s gender or sexual orientation.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury from the picture given below: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incised looking lacerated wound

 

The image shows a lacerated wound which looks like incised wound. This is also called “Incised looking lacerated wound”. They occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

They can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:

 

  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laceration: Irregular tear-like wounds caused by blunt trauma. They often have jagged edges and may have tissue bridges at the base. The wound in the image appears cleaner and more linear, resembling an incised wound, making it an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Option B. Incised wound: Clean, straight cuts typically caused by sharp instruments such as knives or glass. The wound in the image is caused by blunt force and has characteristics of a laceration, despite its appearance.

 

Option C. Lacerated looking incised wound:  In areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc, the shapes are zigzag type. So, although it is produced by sharp weapon but it looks like lacerated wound. Such wounds are sometimes called as lacerated looking incised wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An incised looking lacerated wound is caused by blunt force trauma but appears similar to an incised wound due to its location and the characteristics of the tissue involved.

questions.text: What is the causative agent for Hooch tragedy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Methanol

 

Hooch tragedy is due to the consumption of adulterated liquor containing methanol. Methanol is a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health issues including blindness, metabolic acidosis, and death when ingested.

 

Hooch

 

  • Definition: It is ethyl alcohol illegally adulterated with other harmful substances
  • Methanol as adulterant: A common harmful adulterant in hooch is methanol
  • Sources of methanol in Ethanol: There are two ways by which methanol gets added in the ethanol:
    • Added deliberately to ethanol due to its low price or
    • Produced during ethanol production (fermentation): Methanol can get naturally produced along with ethanol during the production of ethanol by fermentation. Usually it gets removed by distillation, but in local and illegal production, the distillation is of poor quality.
  • Hooch tragedy in India: In India, local alcohol is made illegally from cane sugar, is sold very cheap for a plastic pouch or glass. In Bihar and some other states, it has resulted in deaths of multiple people at different times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning usually occurs due to ingestion of substances like rodenticides or fireworks and is not associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning occurs from exposure to mercury or its compounds and is not linked to hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethanol: Ethanol is the intended product of alcoholic beverages. It is not the cause of hooch tragedies unless it is adulterated with toxic substances like methanol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hooch tragedies occur due to the consumption of illicitly brewed liquor contaminated with methanol, a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health effects including death.

questions.text:
Arrange symptoms as in their order of appearance as seen in iron toxicity:(INICET MAY 2021)

  1. Pyloric stricture
  2. Asymptomatic phase
  3. Gastrointestinal bleeding
  4. Liver failure and hypoglycemia
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 → 2 → 4 → 1

 

Iron toxicity progresses through several stages, each with distinct symptoms that appear in a specific order. The stages are:

 

 

Treatment of Iron toxicity – Deferoxamine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron toxicity progresses through distinct stages, starting with gastrointestinal irritation and bleeding, followed by an asymptomatic phase, then liver failure and hypoglycemia, and finally, bowel obstruction leading to pyloric stricture.

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

 

The image shows multiple wounds on the hand, indicative of defense wounds. These are injuries received by a victim of an attack while trying to defend against the assailant.

 

Defense wounds are typically found on the hands and forearms, showing deep incised or blunt force injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antemortem wound: Wounds inflicted before death, characterized by bleeding, clot formation, and tissue reaction. Defense wounds are a type of antemortem wound, but the specific context here is self-defense.

 

Option C. Postmortem wound: Wounds inflicted after death, characterized by the absence of vital reactions such as bleeding and clotting.

 

Option D. Hesitation cuts: Multiple, small, superficial incised wounds made by a person during a suicide attempt while hesitating to make a final decisive cut.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Marbling

 

  • The post mortem change shown above is marbling.

  • In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postmortem lividity: This is the settling of blood in the lower parts of the body after death, causing a purplish-red discoloration. It does not produce the distinct streaks seen in marbling.

 

Option C. Filigree burns: These are burns that produce a lace-like pattern on the skin, usually caused by electrical injuries. They do not match the appearance shown in the image.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous emphysema: This occurs when air is trapped under the skin, often due to trauma or infection, leading to a characteristic crackling sensation when pressed. It does not produce the streaked pattern seen in marbling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black streaks on the skin due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin, becoming prominent 24-48 hours after death.

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16

 

Fingerprints begin to form between 12 to 16 weeks of intrauterine life. By this stage, the basic patterns of the ridges on the skin are established. The formation continues, and fingerprints are complete by approximately 24 weeks of intrauterine life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fingerprints start developing between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life and are completed by 24 weeks, providing a unique identification for the individual that remains unchanged throughout their life.

choices.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

 

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups.

 

Rigor mortis begins from the head and progresses down the body. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

 

  1. Myocardium
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis

 

Rigor mortis is the post-mortem stiffening and contraction of muscles in the body, resulting from the depletion of energy stores, usually becoming noticeable a few hours after death and gradually resolving over time.”

 

  • It first affects the involuntary muscles first starting with the myocardium
  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis in voluntary muscles
  • Order of appearance of Rigor mortis in different organs:

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

H/O consumption of a fruit, high fever, confusion, photophobia, unable to urinate are anticholinergic symptoms. Photophobia occurs due to mydriasis in anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.

 

Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.

 

Features of Datura poisoning:

 

 D's of Datura

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death

 

Datura Flowers: Flowers are large tubular (trumpet-shaped) which may be white (alba) or purple (Niger)

 

Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains 50 to 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which bear a superficial resemblance to chilly seeds

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning: Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug, physostigmine [Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity]

 

Below image shows Datura Flower and Datura Fruit

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. While Datura is the correct causative agent, Pralidoxime is not the correct antidote. Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. Yellow oleander poisoning presents primarily with symptoms of cardiac toxicity, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, not the anticholinergic symptoms described in the question. Additionally, Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect. Again, Yellow oleander would cause symptoms related to cardiac toxicity rather than the anticholinergic symptoms presented. Physostigmine is not the antidote for Yellow oleander poisoning.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • Types:
  1. Nerium odorum (White Oleander): Bears white, dark red or pink flowers
  2. Cerbera thevetia (Yellow Oleander): Bears yellow bell-shaped flowers, globular fruits

 

 

  • Symptoms: In both oleanders there will symptoms of heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse) and muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. They are similar to digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine is useful in the management of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and bigeminy.
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies (digoxin-specific Fab fragments) are the treatment of choice for severe bradyarrhythmia’s with hypotension unresponsive to atropine and life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

 

  • Lot of blackening is easily visible around the firearm wound in the image.
  • Burning, blackening and tattooing are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds typically do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are generally larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds lack the features of burning, blackening, and tattooing. The wound edges are usually cleaner.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Similar to close shot exit wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not have burning, blackening, or tattooing and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text:
Which of the features given below is of a male pelvis?

 

  1. Triangular obturator foramen

  2. U-shaped pubic angle

  3. Everted ischial tuberosity

  4. Large greater sciatic notch

  5. Large acetabulum

  6. Deep preauricular sulcus
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only 5   

 

Large acetabulum: The acetabulum in males is generally larger to support a greater range of motion and the weight of a more muscular body.

 

Other Features:

 

1. Triangular obturator foramen: Typically seen in males.

 

2. U-shaped pubic angle: This is more characteristic of the female pelvis, which has a wider pubic angle to facilitate childbirth.

 

3. Everted ischial tuberosity: This is more common in females.

 

4. Large greater sciatic notch: More pronounced in females.

 

6. Deep preauricular sulcus: More commonly seen in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between male and female pelvis

questions.text: Identify the article in the constitution that is not related to pediatrics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 42

 

Article 42 says that the state shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief. It is not directly related to pediatrics but rather focuses on the welfare of workers and maternity benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Articles in constitution related to children:

 

Option A. Article 21 A: Right to free and compulsory elementary education in the 6 -14-year age group.

 

Option B. Article 24: Right to be protected from any hazardous employment till 14 years of age.

 

Option C. Article 39 E: Right to be protected from being abused.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 42 is not related to pediatrics, as it focuses on working conditions and maternity relief, unlike Articles 21A, 24, and 39E, which are specifically aimed at the rights and protection of children.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

 

Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning. It is a corrosive acid, but it hardens the Gl mucosa thus anesthetizing its nerve endings and allows for gastric lavage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulphuric acid: A concentrated inorganic acid that can cause severe corrosion and softening of the stomach wall, making gastric lavage dangerous due to the risk of perforation.

 

Option B. Strychnine: A convulsive poison that increases the risk of aspiration during seizures, making gastric lavage unsafe.

 

Option D. Kerosene oil: A volatile hydrocarbon that poses a significant risk of aspiration pneumonitis if gastric lavage is performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraindications to gastric lavage:

 

  1. Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation (exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  2. Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients, Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  3. Upper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices
  4. Hypothermia
  5. Hemorrhagic diathesis

questions.text: A patient alleges negligence by a surgeon and sues him for the same. In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 3 days

 

In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within 72 hours/ 3 days.

 

The treating doctor has to maintain the medical records of the patients for a period of three years as per the regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEDICAL RECORDS

 

1. Duration of retention of records –

  • Digital Records – 10 years
  • Hard copy – 
  • OPD patients: 3 years
  • Indoor patients: 3 years
  • MLC: 10 years

2. Time to provide records – 3 days

3. What if records not maintained – punished for infamous conduct

questions.text: Identify the plant (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebra Thevetia

 

Explanation:

 

Cerebra Thevetia (Yellow Oleander): This plant is identified by its yellow, bell-shaped flowers. It is also known as a cardiotoxic plant. The yellow oleander typically has these distinct flowers and should be recognized for its toxic properties.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerium Odorum (White Oleander): White in color and not bell-shaped flower. It is also cardiotoxic.

 

 

Option C. Aconite: Also known as monk's hood, Aconite has hood-like flowers. It is characterized by a hood-like upper part and two-lipped lower part.

 

 

Option D. Cerbera odollam: Also known as the "suicide tree", it produces white flowers, mango like fruit and this is also cardiotoxic.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander) - Yellow, bell-shaped flowers, a cardiotoxic plant.

 

Nerium Odorum (White Oleander) - White and flowers are not bell-shaped, also cardiotoxic

 

Note – Other Important flowers

 

Trumpet shape flower – Datura

 

 

Digitalis Purpura flowers – arranged in elongated clusters, flower is tubular & pendant. Inside of the flower is heavily spotted

questions.text: As per the latest MTP act, termination of failed contraception is allowed till which weeks of contraception? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20 weeks

 

The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act allows for the termination of pregnancy under specific conditions. For failed contraception, termination is permitted up to 20 weeks of pregnancy. This is because the law recognizes that contraceptive failure can occur, and it allows individuals the right to terminate the pregnancy within this timeframe.

 

Note –

 

  • Termination up to 24 weeks is only allowed under specific conditions such as rape, fetal anomalies, or if the woman is disabled.
  • Termination beyond 24 weeks is only permitted in cases of congenital anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MTP Act permits termination of pregnancy due to failed contraception up to 20 weeks.

questions.text: What is a characteristic feature of a contact gunshot wound? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stellate wound

 

Explanation:


A stellate wound is a hallmark of contact gunshot wounds, particularly when the gun is fired against a firm surface like the skull. The gases and pressure from the gunshot cause the skin to burst and tear radially, creating a star-shaped, or stellate, pattern. This type of wound is caused by the high-pressure gases and thermal effects of the discharge directly impacting and penetrating the skin at the point of contact.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Abraded collar: Incorrect for this context, as an abraded collar is typical of close, but not necessarily contact, shots where the bullet scrapes the skin upon entry.


Option C. Grease collar:  Incorrect, this refers to a deposit from the bullet or barrel, not typically prominent in contact shots due to the nature of the discharge.


Option  D. Tattooing: Incorrect for contact shots, as tattooing from unburned powder particles occurs at close range but outside of direct contact.

 

Educational Objective:


Stellate wounds are indicative of contact gunshot wounds due to the close proximity of the firearm's muzzle at the time of discharge.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male addicted to recreational drugs, smoking and alcohol came to the OPD with complaints of excessive beating of heart and palpitations. On examination, there was episodic tachycardia and occasional extrasystole. Ophthalmic examination showed visual field defects. Which of the drugs is the likely cause?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cocaine

 

This is a sympathomimetic features (tachycardia, palpitation, arrhythmia like extrasystole) which are typical features of cocaine. Visual field defects can also occur with cocaine (due to vasoconstriction, and ischemia) though it is not common.

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and CVS:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious CVS Effects: Arrhythmias, Extrasystole, Myocardial Infarction
  • Seizures, Confusion 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nicotine:

 

  • While nicotine can cause tachycardia and palpitations, but they are more pronounced and more common feature of cocaine.
  • Extrasystole are not a typical effect of nicotine use.
  • Nicotine does not cause visual Field Defects

 

Option C. Cannabis:

 

  • Cannabis usually causes mild symptoms, and mainly in CNS (Euphoria, altered perception, impaired cognitive function)
  • Tachycardia caused by cannabis is mild, not arrhythmias or palpitation
  • It does not cause visual field defects

 

Option D. Atropine:

 

  • Atropine is not typically a recreational drug.
  • Atropine causes moderate and controlled tachycardia, but not “episodic” tachycardia or extrasystole. Palpitations are more likely with cocaine as it is sympathomimetic.
  • Atropine can cause temporary mydriasis, but not visual field defects

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug that causes significant stimulant effects on the CNS and CVS, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia, palpitations, arrhythmias, and, occasionally, visual field defects due to vasoconstriction and ischemia.

questions.text: The ossification center of the clavicle used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sternal end

 

Explanation:

 

The sternal end of the clavicle is significant in determining bone age, as it is the last epiphysis in the body to fuse with the shaft. This secondary ossification center appears around the age of 19-20 years and unites with the shaft by the age of 25 years. The radiological appearance of this epiphysis is particularly useful in females to confirm their bone age for legal purposes, such as consent to marriage.

 

Ossification Centres of Clavicle

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromial end: The secondary ossification center at the acromial end appears and fuses almost immediately around the 20th year but is not typically used for determining bone age for legal purposes.

 

Option C. Shaft: The primary ossification centers of the shaft appear during fetal life, but they are not relevant for assessing bone age in the context of legal consent to marriage.

 

Option D. Tubercle: There is no significant role of the tubercle in determining bone age for legal purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sternal end of the clavicle is used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage, as it is the last epiphysis in the body to fuse with the shaft.

choices.text: He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol
He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence

questions.text: In an examination for drunkenness, a person smells of alcohol and his conjunctiva appear red. During his motor examination, it is observed that he can walk in a straight line and can talk normally. Which of the following statements is true?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence

 

The presented situation depicts an individual emitting the scent of alcohol, yet their motor coordination remains unaffected, and there is no slurring of speech. This suggests that they might have consumed alcohol previously, but they are not currently under its influence.

 

If the individual were unable to walk in a straight line or displayed slurred speech, they would be considered under the influence of alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. He has consumed alcohol: This statement is true, but it does not address the influence of alcohol on the person's abilities.

 

Option B. He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol: This statement would be true if there were signs of impaired motor coordination or slurred speech, which are not present in this case.

 

Option D. He has not consumed alcohol: This statement is false as the smell of alcohol and red conjunctiva indicate consumption of alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood-Alcohol Concentration and Symptoms:

questions.text: Study of all aspects of death is called as: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thanatology

 

Thanatology is the scientific study of death, dying, and the processes surrounding them.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traumatology: The study of injuries and wounds, including their medical treatment and repair.

 

Option C. Toxicology: The study of the adverse effects of chemicals on living organisms, especially the poisoning effects of drugs and chemicals.

 

Option D. Epidemiology: The study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states or events in specific populations and the application of this study to control health problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thanatology is the field that comprehensively studies death and the various aspects associated with it.

questions.text: Identify the following image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Blister due to antemortem burns

 

The antemortem blister presents itself as an elevated dome, containing serous fluid enriched with proteins and chlorides. The surrounding base exhibits reddening and swollen papillae. In the case of antemortem burns, the adjacent skin displays heightened enzyme activity, particularly for sulfhydryl groups in all skin layers. This reaction is accompanied by increased levels of ATP, esterase’s, aminopeptidases, acid, and alkaline phosphatase. These vital reactions indicate notable cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes, which are distinctive features of antemortem burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blister due to barbiturate poisoning: Barbiturate poisoning typically causes CNS depression, respiratory issues, and cardiovascular problems, not specific blister formation like burns.

 

Option C. Edema due to chemical burn: Chemical burns might cause edema, but the specific blister shown in the image is more characteristic of thermal burns.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris: Pemphigus vulgaris presents with flaccid blisters and erosions rather than the tense blister shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antemortem burn blisters are characterized by elevated domes filled with serous fluid, reddened surrounding base, and high enzyme activity, indicating significant cellular and tissue reactions distinct from other types of blisters or burns.

questions.text: The last organ to be affected by rigor mortis among the following is: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Toes

 

Explanation:

 

  • Nysten's law describes the progression of rigor mortis in both voluntary and involuntary muscles
  • In this progression: 
    • Involuntary muscles (myocardium) are affected first
    • Then follows a cephalocaudal progression in voluntary muscles: 
      • Upper eyelids
      • Neck and jaw muscles
      • Face
      • Chest
      • Upper limbs
      • Abdomen
      • Lower limbs
      • Fingers and toes being the last
  • The progression follows Nysten's law both in: 
    • Development (ascending order)
    • Disappearance (same order)
  • Time frame follows the "rule of 12": 
    • Takes 12 hours to develop fully
    • Persists for 12 hours
    • Disappears over 12 hours

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand the sequential progression of rigor mortis following Nysten's law, emphasizing the pattern of involvement from heart to the most distal parts of the body, which is crucial for establishing time since death in forensic investigations.

choices.text: Place them in same plastic bag and seat it for preservation
Preserve in envelope or paper bag
Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together
Place them in different plastic bags and seal for preservation

questions.text: 2 handkerchiefs with blood stains are found at a crime scene. What is the most appropriate procedure for handling these items? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Preserve in envelope or paper bag

 

When handling blood-stained handkerchiefs or any other stained items found at a crime scene, it is crucial to follow the appropriate procedure to ensure the preservation of evidence. The most suitable method is to preserve the handkerchiefs in an envelope or paper bag, which allows for air circulation. This prevents the growth of mold and bacteria that can occur when moisture is trapped in non-porous containers like plastic bags.

 

Additionally, it is important to dry the stains, but this should be done in the shade or by air drying. Exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat can denature the DNA, compromising the evidence. Therefore, using a spirit lamp or any other heating material to dry the stains is not recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A & D. Place them in same/different plastic bag and seal it for preservation: Plastic bags should be avoided as they can trap moisture, leading to the growth of mold and bacteria, which can compromise the evidence.

 

Option. C. Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together: Folding the handkerchiefs with the stained edges together can lead to the mixing of stains, making it difficult to distinguish between the stains from different individuals, if applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When handling blood-stained items found at a crime scene, preserve them in an envelope or paper bag to allow for air circulation, and dry the stains in the shade or by air drying to prevent DNA denaturation. Avoid using plastic bags or exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat.

questions.text: Match the postmortem findings and their time of appearance:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Postmortem changes occur in a sequential manner and can be used to estimate the time since death. The matching of these findings with their respective times of appearance is as follows:

 

  1. Adipocere formation
    • Time of appearance: 8-10 days
    • Explanation: Adipocere, also known as grave wax, is a postmortem change that occurs when body fat undergoes a transformation into a waxy substance in a moist environment. This process typically begins around 8-10 days after death.
  2. Relaxation of urethral sphincter
    • Time of appearance: 24 hrs
    • Explanation: After death, muscle relaxation, including the relaxation of the urethral sphincter, occurs due to the cessation of neural activity and muscle tone, typically around 24 hours postmortem.
  3. Marbling of veins
    • Time of appearance: 2-3 days
    • Explanation: Marbling refers to the appearance of greenish-black discoloration along the veins due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the production of hydrogen sulphide gas by bacteria. This occurs approximately 2-3 days after death.
  4. Liquefaction of tissues
    • Time of appearance: 4-5 days
    • Explanation: Tissue liquefaction is a stage of decomposition where tissues start to break down into a liquid form. This process typically begins around 4-5 days postmortem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amongst postmortem findings:

 

  • Adipocere formation is by 8-10 days
  • Relaxation of urethral sphincter is by 24 hrs.
  • Marbling of veins is by 2-3 days
  • Liquefaction of tissues is by 4-5 days

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.text: The dead body of a 4-year-old child who was playing around the riverside and accidentally drowned in the river is recovered. There is frothing seen from his mouth and nose. Which of the below postmortem findings is not seen in a case of drowning? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to antemortem drowning.

 

This finding is unrelated to drowning and would suggest chronic arsenic poisoning rather than an acute drowning incident.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway
  • Water in the stomach and small intestine
  • Water in middle ear
  • Cerebral edema
  • Bloated and cyanosed face
  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.
  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs
  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils
  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours
  • Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist 
  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voluminous and ballooned out lungs: Seen in drowning due to the inhalation of water.

 

Option C. Paltauf's hemorrhage in sub pleura: Hemorrhages found beneath the pleura, associated with drowning.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist: Indicates a struggle and is a sign of antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of drowning, typical findings include frothing from the mouth and nose, voluminous lungs, and cadaveric spasm with debris. High arsenic concentration in hair shafts is not associated with drowning.

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullet

 

The image shows a circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull, which is characteristic of a bullet wound. Beveling of the outer table indicates an exit wound, while beveling of the inner table would indicate an entry wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scissor: Incorrect. Scissor injuries typically produce irregular, non-circular wounds with sharp edges, not the circular hole seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rod: Incorrect. Injuries from a rod would usually result in linear or irregular wounds, depending on the shape and force of impact, not a circular hole.

 

Option C. Axe: Incorrect. An axe would cause a large, irregular, and typically more extensive laceration with sharp, defined edges, not a circular hole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a patient that presented to the  emergency with flame burn injury covering the entire  chest and abdomen, the entire right upper limb and full circumference of the  right thigh.(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 36

 

To calculate the percentage of body surface area affected by burns, the Rule of Nines is often used in adults. This method divides the body into sections that represent 9% (or multiples thereof) of the body surface area.

 

As per the case scenario given :

 

  • Chest and abdomen: 18%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Right thigh: 9%

 

Total = 18% (chest and abdomen) + 9% (right upper limb) + 9% (right thigh) = 36%

 

Educational Objective:

 

This calculation as per the case scenario and Wallace rule of 9 results in a total burned body surface area of 36%, which corresponds to option B.

 

Rule of Nine

questions.text: A female worker from a pyrotechnic factory presents with bone pain, multiple fractures, anemia, and renal dysfunction. On examination, her jaw shows brownish discoloration of teeth without necrosis. What is the most likely causative agent? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cadmium

 

Explanation: 

 

The presentation suggests chronic cadmium toxicity ("Itai-itai disease"), characterized by:

  • Osteomalacia and osteoporosis leading to multiple fractures
  • Renal tubular dysfunction
  • Anemia
  • Dental manifestations including brown discoloration
  • Common in industrial exposure (batteries, pigments, pyrotechnics)

 

Other Incorrect Options:

 

Option A. Phosphorus

  • Causes osteonecrosis of jaw ("phossy jaw")
  • Presents with jaw pain, loose teeth, fistulae
  • Associated with match factory workers
  • Does not cause systemic bone disease

 

Option B. Antimony

  • Primarily causes respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms
  • No significant bone or renal involvement
  • Used in flame retardants and electronics
  • Dental changes not characteristic

 

Option D. Fluorine

  • Causes dental and skeletal fluorosis
  • Presents with mottled teeth (white patches)
  • No significant renal involvement
  • Does not cause anemia

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand:

  • Different industrial toxins can affect bone metabolism
  • Importance of distinguishing systemic vs. localized bone pathology
  • Characteristic features of various heavy metal toxicities
  • Role of workplace exposure in diagnosis

questions.text: Sequence of Rigor Mortis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head to foot

 

Rigor mortis is the postmortem stiffening of muscles due to biochemical changes in the muscle tissues after death. It typically starts within 2 hours after death, beginning with the myocardium (heart muscle). Externally, the sequence begins at the upper eyelids and then follows a top-to-bottom approach throughout the body.

 

The progression of rigor mortis occurs in three stages:

 

  • Developing Stage (First 12 hours): Rigor begins at the upper parts of the body and progresses downwards.
  • Fully Developed Stage (Next 12 hours): Rigor mortis is fully established.
  • Passing Stage (Last 12 hours): Rigor mortis diminishes in the same order, starting from the head and moving downwards, eventually leading to secondary flaccidity.

 

This sequence is known as Nysten's Rule, which describes rigor mortis development from head to foot, with the exact order being eyelids, neck, jaw, face, chest, upper limbs, abdomen, lower limbs, and finally fingers and toes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Centre to periphery: This option incorrectly suggests that rigor mortis progresses from the center of the body outward, which does not align with the actual top-to-bottom sequence of rigor mortis development.

 

Option C. Foot to head: This option is incorrect as rigor mortis follows a head-to-foot sequence, not the reverse.

 

Option D. Periphery to centre: This option is incorrect because rigor mortis does not start at the outer parts of the body and move inward; instead, it progresses from the head down towards the feet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis follows a sequence known as Nysten's Rule, developing and passing from head to foot, starting with the upper body and ending with the lower extremities.

questions.text: A vagabond roaming in the forest eats some unknown fruits. After sometime he starts having symptoms of irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

Diagnostic features of Datura poisoning in the question

 

  • Datura has mainly neurotoxic (Irritability, restlessness) and anticholinergic features (Dry hot skin, unable to urinate and pass stool)
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for Datura

 

Datura poisoning:

 

  • Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.
  • Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.
  • Features of Datura poisoning (D's of Datura): Dry hot skin, Dilatation of pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium, Drowsiness, Death.
  • Datura causes constipation, not diarrhoea

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning:

 

  • Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug.
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice
  • Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning, not for anticholinergic toxicity caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside and not an antidote. The treatment for yellow oleander poisoning includes atropine and antiarrhythmics, not digoxin.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Physostigmine is not the antidote for yellow oleander poisoning, which primarily affects the heart rather than causing anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • There are two oleander plants: Nerium odorum and Cerbera Thevetia
  • Both are cardiac poisons
  • Both have digoxin like toxicity:
    • Heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse).
    • Similar to digitalis.
    •  Muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning.
  • Treatment of Both Oleander poisoning:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies for severe arrhythmias

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning is characterized by neurotoxic and anticholinergic symptoms, and the appropriate antidote is Physostigmine, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and reverse CNS toxicity.

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

 

  • Paradoxical undressing is seen in hypothermia victims.
  • The victims, despite low environmental temperatures, paradoxically remove their clothes due to a sudden feeling of warmth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat stress: Heat stress leads to symptoms such as heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke, characterized by elevated body temperature, dehydration, and sometimes loss of consciousness. It does not cause paradoxical undressing.

 

Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a psychiatric condition where an individual derives sexual pleasure from observing unsuspecting people who are naked, undressing, or engaging in sexual activities. It is unrelated to hypothermia or paradoxical undressing.

 

Option D. LSD overdose: LSD overdose can cause hallucinations, altered mental status, and sensory distortions. While individuals may engage in bizarre behaviors, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom of LSD overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical undressing occurs in hypothermia victims who, despite experiencing extremely low temperatures, remove their clothing due to a sudden and misleading sensation of warmth.

questions.text: During a police investigation, bones are uncovered at the crime scene. What key characteristic feature would be crucial in differentiating between human and animal bones, aiding forensic analysis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Precipitin test

 

When differentiating between human and animal bones found at a crime scene, the key characteristic feature that aids forensic analysis is the species-specific differentiation. In such cases, regardless of the type of tissue (e.g., blood, semen, tissues, or bone), the precipitin test is the test of choice. In the precipitin test, an extract of the bone, tissue, or stain is taken, and an anti-human serum is added to it. If the sample is of human origin, a precipitate will form, indicating a positive result for human tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Acid phosphatase: Acid phosphatase is a specific test used for detecting semen and is not relevant for differentiating between human and animal bones.

 

Option. C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is another test used for detecting semen and is not applicable for differentiating between human and animal bones.

 

Option. D. Phenolphthalein test : This test is a presumptive test to detect blood stain. Also known as (Kastle-Meyer) test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The precipitin test is the key characteristic feature used to differentiate between human and animal bones found at a crime scene. This test is species-specific and can be applied to various tissues, including blood, semen, and bones. The formation of a precipitate upon the addition of an anti-human serum to the sample extract indicates the presence of human tissue.

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth. (BNS 229)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (up to 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 7 years. (BNS 238)

choices.text: Breadth of fifth lumbar vertebra X 100 breadth of all sacral vertebra
Breadth of first sacral vertebra X 100 / breadth of fifth lumbar vertebra
Breadth of fifth lumbar vertebra X 100 / breadth of base of sacrum
Breadth of first sacral vertebra X 100 / breadth of base of sacrum

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding corporobasal index of the sacrum? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Breadth of first sacral vertebra X 100 / breadth of base of sacrum

 

  • Corporobasal index helps in determining the sex of the individual from the pelvis.
  • Corporobasal index = Breadth of first sacral vertebra x 100 / breadth of the base of the sacrum.
  • In males, it is >42 and in females, it is <42.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corporobasal index is calculated using the breadth of the first sacral vertebra and the breadth of the base of the sacrum, which helps in determining the sex of the individual.

 

Other Indices for Anthropometric Measurements:

choices.text: Distribution pattern in summer vs winter

questions.text: In a case of drowning, the following organism was isolated from the internal organs. Which finding is diagnostic in this case? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence in bone marrow

 

The organism shown is a diatom, and its presence specifically in bone marrow is considered the most diagnostic finding in drowning cases. While diatoms can be found in various organs, their detection in bone marrow is particularly significant because:

 

  1. Bone marrow is a closed system, protected from external contamination
  2. Diatoms can only reach bone marrow through active circulation during drowning
  3. Post-mortem contamination rarely affects bone marrow

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Large numbers in gastric contents: Incorrect because diatoms in gastric contents could result from ingestion of water before death and don't necessarily indicate drowning.

 

Option C. Finding in decomposed bodies: Incorrect as diatom testing becomes unreliable in decomposed bodies due to post-mortem contamination and tissue breakdown.

 

Option D. Distribution pattern in summer vs winter: Incorrect because while seasonal variations affect diatom populations in water bodies, this doesn't affect their diagnostic value in drowning cases.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the significance of diatom testing in drowning cases, particularly the importance of bone marrow sampling as the most reliable diagnostic site due to its protection from post-mortem contamination.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was taken by her neighbour to the emergency department after an incident involving her husband. She reported that during a domestic altercation, her husband swung an axe at her left arm. Upon examination, a significant injury was observed on her upper left arm. The wound appeared deep, with jagged and irregular edges. The surrounding area showed signs of bruising. Based on the clinical scenario, what type of wound is likely to be present on the patient's upper left arm? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chop wound 

 

A heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, e.g. axe produces chop wounds. Chop wounds have features of both sharp and blunt force injuries. They are characterized by deep, jagged, and irregular edges with surrounding bruising.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incised wound:

 

  • Produced by lighter weapons like knife, blades etc.
  • Margins are not contused and abraded. 
  • Destruction of underlying tissues is less as compared to cop wound.

 

Option C. Lacerated wound:

 

  • Lacerations can result from accidents, falls, or impact with blunt objects.
  • Lacerated wounds are not clean cut, whereas incised and chop wounds are clean cut.

 

Option D. Abrasion:  In abrasions only the superficial skin is damaged. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cut laceration / chop wounds: 

 

  • Produced by a heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, E.g. axe, chopper
    • It has features of both blunt force (bruised and abraded margins, irregular margins) and sharp force (clean margins)
    • A deep and wide cut over the body tissues.
    • Marked destruction of underlying tissues
    • Below image shows chop wound by axe:

questions.text: Match the following in relation to fingerprint changes: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-e, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a, 5-d

 

The changes in fingerprints can be associated with various medical conditions and external factors:

 

  1. Incomplete atrophy of ridges - E. Dermatitis:
    • Dermatitis can cause inflammation and swelling, leading to incomplete atrophy of the fingerprint ridges.
  2. Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy - C. Celiac disease:
    • Celiac disease can cause skin changes and atrophy of the fingerprint ridges, leading to the loss of pattern.
  3. Altered ridges - B. Scleroderma:
    • Scleroderma causes hardening and tightening of the skin, which can alter the fingerprint ridges.
  4. Permanent loss of fingerprints - A. Radiation:
    • Exposure to radiation can cause permanent damage to the skin, leading to the permanent loss of fingerprints.
  5. Distance between ridges is changed but pattern is retained - D. Acromegaly:
    • In acromegaly, there is an increase in the growth of bones and tissues, which can change the distance between fingerprint ridges while retaining the overall pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fissured 

 

Image shows thin lines, which are not displaced. This is characteristic of fissured (linear) #

 

Fissured (linear) fractures present as thin, non-displaced lines and are the most common type of skull fracture, typically resulting from broad surface impacts, such as in road traffic accidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ring Fracture: Caused by a fall from height, presenting as a fracture around the foramen magnum.

 

Option B. Depressed Fracture: Caused by heavy objects with a small surface area, takes the shape of the weapon.

 

Option D. Hinge Fracture: Divides the skull into anterior and posterior halves, often associated with motorcyclist injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Skull fractures 

 

  1. Linear fracture/ primary fracture/ fissured fracture                                                 
    • Fracture looks like a thin line 
    • Due to striking with a broad surface, e.g. ground 
    • Most common skull fracture, 
    • Usually seen in Road traffic accident
       

  2. Depressed fracture/ signature fracture 

    • Due to a heavy objects with small surface area . e.g. hammer 
    • Takes the shape of the weapon 

     

  3. Indented fracture / ping pong fracture / ponds #
    • Skull is depressed like a ping pong ball 
    • Seen in infants 
       
  4. Gutter fracture 
    • Long narrow depressed fracture 
    • Bullet passing adjacent to skull 
       
  5. Sutural fracture / diastatic fracture 
    • Sutures separate
    • Seen In <3 yrs of age 
       
  6. Ring fracture 
    • Cause – fall from height 
    • # around foramen magnum 
    • Associated # of vertebrae 
       
  7. Hinge fracture / motorcyclist fracture 
    • Skull divided into anterior and posterior halves 
       
  8. Spider web fracture / mosaic fracture / comminuted fracture 
    • Multiple fractures of skull

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used to assess the blood stain? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barberio’s test

 

Barberio test is a microchemical test for Semen

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Additional Information

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR SEMEN

 

1) Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

choices.text: The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium.
It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots.
This rule involves the observation of fracture lines.
It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously.

questions.text: Regarding Puppe's rule, all of the following statements are true EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously.

 

Explanation:

 

Puppe's rule is specifically applied to determine the sequence of multiple gunshot wounds to the skull when they do not occur simultaneously. The rule states that an extending fracture line will stop at a pre-existing fracture line or suture, indicating the sequence in which the impacts occurred. Thus, it cannot accurately determine the sequence when gunshot injuries happen virtually simultaneously, as the fractures may overlap or intersect ambiguously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium: because Puppe's rule does indeed pertain to bullet injuries of the cranium, specifically to establish the order of multiple impacts based on fracture lines.

 

Option B. It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots: as this statement is true; Puppe's rule helps in determining the chronological order of gunshot wounds by examining the interaction of fracture lines.

 

Option C. This rule involves the observation of fracture lines: because observing fracture lines is a fundamental aspect of applying Puppe's rule to ascertain the order of injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Puppe's rule cannot be used to determine the sequence of bullet injuries when they occur simultaneously due to overlapping and intersecting fracture lines.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Labia majora - separated
  • Labia minora- flabby
  • Fourchette tear present
  • Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen

 

What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False virgin

 

The observed separated labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not a virgin. Despite having sexual intercourse, the hymen is intact so it is a case of false virgin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True virgin: Presence of labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not true virgin.

 

Option C. Premenstrual change typically involve hormonal variations leading to breast tenderness, bloating, and mood swings rather than observable alterations in genital anatomy.

 

Option D. Molestation there would be sign of abrasions, bruising, edema, laceration or may have injuries to the vulva, hymen, vagina and the perineum. Since these signs are not present chances of molestation are slim

 

Educational  Objective:

 

Please note that the features will be same for a deflorate woman and a false virgin with the exception of presence of hymen in the latter.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and was brought to emergency with stable vitals. Which wound is not expected:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chop wound

 

In the context of a road traffic accident, different types of wounds can be expected depending on the nature of the injury.

 

Chop Wound typically caused by a heavy, sharp tool like an axe or a machete. These are not typically seen in road traffic accidents unless there is a very specific scenario involving such an implement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Bruises: These are common in road traffic accidents due to blunt force trauma where the body strikes objects like the steering wheel, dashboard, or gets jostled against seat belts.

 

Option C. Graze Abrasion: Often occurs when the skin slides across a rough surface, such as in motorcycle accidents when the rider is dragged along the pavement.

 

Option D. Laceration: These are irregular tears in the skin commonly caused by blunt trauma, which is typical in road traffic accidents when sharp or rough metal edges and glass are involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chop wounds are unusual in road traffic accidents .

questions.text: Which organ is the earliest to undergo putrefaction from the given options? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brain

 

Among the given options, the brain is the first organ to undergo putrefaction. The process of putrefaction involves the decomposition of body tissues and follows a specific order from early to late stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart: The heart putrefies after the brain but before the kidneys.

 

Option C. Kidney: The kidneys putrefy after the heart.

 

Option D. Prostate: The prostate putrefies very late in the process, even after the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The order of organ putrefaction (early to late) is as follows:

 

  1. Larynx and trachea
  2. Liver and lungs
  3. Brain
  4. Heart
  5. Kidney
  6. Prostate and Non Gravid uterus
  7. Skin, muscle, tendons
  8. Bones and teeth

 

Prostate and Non gravid uterus are organs which putrefy very late. The gravid uterus putrefies earlier.

 

Mnemonic: LBHK

 

L for larynx, liver, lungs, B for brain H for Heart, K for Kidney

questions.text: Black foot is seen in which poisoning: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

Blackfoot disease is an endemic peripheral vascular disease found among the inhabitants of a limited area on the southwest coast of Taiwan, where well water with a high concentration of arsenic causes peripheral vascular disease resulting in gangrene.

 

Other options are incorrect as the term Blackfoot disease is used only for arsenic

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation

 

  • Above picture shows Blackfoot disease:

questions.text: For Medical Termination of Pregnancy after 24 weeks of gestation due to fetal chromosomal abnormalities, whose presence is mandatory in the medical board? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Radiologist

 

Explanation:

 

When conducting a medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks of gestation due to fetal chromosomal abnormalities, the presence of a Radiologist in the medical board is mandatory. The Radiologist plays a crucial role in:

 

  • Interpreting Advanced Imaging: They provide expertise in analyzing detailed ultrasound or other imaging results essential for diagnosing chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Assessing Fetal Anatomy: Radiologists evaluate the structural anomalies that may be associated with chromosomal disorders.
  • Guiding Procedural Decisions: Their input is vital in determining the most appropriate and safe methods for termination based on imaging findings.
  • Collaborating with Other Specialists: They work alongside obstetricians and geneticists to ensure comprehensive evaluation and decision-making.

 

Other Options:

 

  • B. Medical Geneticist:
    • While a Medical Geneticist provides valuable insights into genetic testing and counseling, their presence is not mandated in the medical board for MTP after 24 weeks.
    • Their expertise may be consulted as needed but is not a core requirement.
  • C. General Surgeon:
    • A General Surgeon does not play a direct role in the assessment or decision-making process for MTP due to chromosomal abnormalities.
    • Their surgical skills are not pertinent to the termination procedures in this context.
  • D. Psychiatrist:
    • A Psychiatrist is not required on the medical board for MTP related to chromosomal abnormalities.
    • They may be involved if there are mental health considerations, but their presence is not a standard requirement.

 

Educational Objective:


A Radiologist must be included in the medical board for MTP procedures beyond 24 weeks when fetal chromosomal abnormalities are the indication, ensuring accurate interpretation of imaging and safe termination practices.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

questions.text: In a case of intrauterine fetal demise, which radiological sign shows anechoic areas in the fetal brain parenchyma on ultrasound? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: c. Bohr sign

 

Explanation: 

 

Bohr sign shows postmortem changes in fetal brain including:

  • Anechoic areas in brain parenchyma
  • Occurs due to liquefaction
  • Appears approximately 24-48 hours after fetal death
  • Reliable ultrasound marker of intrauterine demise

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robert's sign

  • Shows gas shadows in fetal heart/great vessels
  • Seen on radiographs, not ultrasound
  • Appears 1-2 days after death
  • Due to blood decomposition

 

Option B. Spalding sign

  • Shows overlapping of skull bones
  • Due to brain tissue collapse
  • Radiological finding
  • May be absent in early deaths

 

Option D. Brain sparing sign

  • Sign of fetal compromise in living fetuses
  • Shows preserved cerebral blood flow
  • Not a sign of fetal death
  • Seen on Doppler ultrasound

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand:

  • Different imaging modalities for confirming fetal death
  • Timeline of various postmortem changes
  • Importance of multiple signs in confirming diagnosis
  • Specificity of different radiological and sonographic signs

questions.text: Which of the following is not a legal rule concerning the criminal responsibility of the insane? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haase's Rule

 

Explanation:

 

Haase's Rule is unrelated to criminal responsibility; it is a method for determining the fetal age based on crown-heel length measurements, indicating the development stages of a fetus. This rule is purely medical and has no bearing on legal assessments of insanity or criminal responsibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  McNaughten’s Rule: as an incorrect choice because McNaughten’s Rule directly pertains to determining criminal responsibility based on the defendant's understanding of right and wrong during the act.

 

Option B. Durham’s Rule: as an incorrect choice because Durham’s Rule assesses criminal responsibility by examining whether the act was a product of mental disease or defect.

 

Option C. Atkin’s Rule: as an incorrect choice because Atkin’s Rule, similar to an irresistible impulse rule, evaluates criminal responsibility based on the defendant's capacity to control his actions due to mental disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haase's Rule is a medical guideline for estimating fetal age and does not deal with the criminal responsibility of the insane.

questions.text: A girl runs away from home with her boyfriend and they get married. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the boy. Identify the approximate age of the girl from the Xray picture of her pelvis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 21 years

 

The ischial tuberosity in the X ray is fused, hence the age is > 21 years

 

Some students can get confused and are not able to distinguish whether ischial tuberosity has fused or not yet appeared. It is not possible that ischial tuberosity has not yet appeared because the upper end of femur (head, greater trochanter, lesser trochanter) has fused with shaft which occurs between 17- 19 years, whereas ischial tuberosity appears earlier at 16 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Femur

 

Upper end of Femur is composed of three centres:

 

  • Head – 1 yr (A)             
  • Greater Trochanter- 4 yr (A)
  • Lesser trochanter – 14 yr (A)          

 

These three centres fuse with shaft at 17- 19 yrs of age

 

Pelvis

choices.text: The medical officer must wait for the presence of the accused and their lawyer before recording the patient's statement.
The medical officer can record the patient's statement, but it is preferable for a magistrate to do so for it to be considered in court.
The medical officer is allowed to ask leading questions to quickly gather all necessary information from the patient.
If the patient unexpectedly recovers, their recorded statement will remain as the primary evidence in court proceedings.

questions.text: During a late-night shift in a district hospital's emergency department, a medical officer is urgently called to attend to a patient with critical injuries from a hit-and-run accident. As the patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, the medical officer realizes the importance of recording the patient's account of the incident, suspecting it might be the patient's dying declaration. Given the urgency of the situation and the legal significance of the patient's statement, which of the following actions aligns best with the protocol for recording a dying declaration in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The medical officer can record the patient's statement, but it is preferable for a magistrate to do so for it to be considered in court.

 

In India, a dying declaration is a statement made by a person who believes they are close to death, concerning the cause of their death or the circumstances surrounding it. Dying declarations are critical in cases of criminal proceedings, especially when the victim may not survive to testify in court.

 

While anyone (including a medical officer) can record a dying declaration, it is preferable for a magistrate to do so because statements recorded by magistrates carry more legal weight in court. However, in urgent cases, such as when a magistrate is not immediately available, a medical officer can record the statement, and it will still be considered valid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The medical officer must wait for the presence of the accused and their lawyer before recording the patient's statement: This is incorrect. There is no legal requirement for the accused or their lawyer to be present when recording a dying declaration. The priority is to record the statement as quickly as possible before the patient’s condition worsens.

 

Option C. The medical officer is allowed to ask leading questions to quickly gather all necessary information from the patient: This is incorrect. The officer must avoid asking leading questions, as they could influence the patient's response and compromise the integrity of the dying declaration.

 

Option D. If the patient unexpectedly recovers, their recorded statement will remain as the primary evidence in court proceedings: This is incorrect. If the patient survives, the dying declaration loses its status as a "dying declaration," and the patient will need to provide a deposition or live testimony in court.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A medical officer is allowed to record a dying declaration in urgent circumstances, though it is preferable for a magistrate to do so. The recorded statement is legally significant but must be taken without leading questions, and the presence of the accused or their lawyer is not required.

questions.text: BNS (Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita) is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Code for punishment

 

Bhartiya nyaya sanhita defines Offences and their Punishments

 

Core concept

 

Categorisation of indian legal acts

 

BNS (earlier IPC) is the principal criminal code of India that defines crimes and provides punishments.

 

BNSS (earlier CrPC) is the rulebook for how criminal cases are handled in India. It spells out the procedures for investigation, arrest, trial, and appeals in criminal matters.

 

BSA (earlier IEA) It’s the law that defines how evidence is presented and accepted in Indian courts during trials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Procedure for investigation: procedures that should be followed during a criminal case is defined under BNSS not under BNS hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Both A and B: this cannot be the answer as choice A is incorrect.

 

Option D. None of the above : this cannot be the answer as Choice B is correct.
